awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Building Human-Technology Safety Partnerships in Roadside Work Zones
awd_abstract_narration:
Highway construction and maintenance is reported as one of the most unsafe occupations in the United States. Road workers are six times more likely to be injured or killed during work, compared with other occupations. In the past two decades, more than 22,000 highway construction and maintenance workers have died due to work-related accidents, which translates to a societal cost of $55 million/year. Nevertheless, alerting a worker to an emergency in real-time is extremely difficult, as the work environment is noisy and chaotic, filled with visual distractions, heavy vibrations, and loud noises. Identifying threats and taking appropriate action is very challenging, especially when the time available to respond is very brief. This project explores the concept of using connected wearable technology to create smart work zones that would enhance workers' safety & comfort. This wearable device would assist workers in identifying and warning of potential threats/hazardous situations, give initial preemptive guidance, and help them find a way to safety. The research team aims 1) to provide virtual reality (VR)-based tools for training workers and 2) to provide agencies and contractors with guidelines for best practices for worker safety in the emerging sociotechnical landscape.

A convergent research team of scientists, public/private stakeholders, and industry partners will  (1) develop an initial prototype of connected wearable devices (Future Technology); (2)  use VR experiments to investigate workers' behavior during hazardous events and safety-related decisions with and without wearable devices (Future Worker); and (3) develop a novel technology acceptance model and quantify the societal/economic benefits of this new human-technology safety partnership (Future Work). Successful project outcomes will be collated into a training-and-learning platform (SHIELD: the Science of Hazard Identification and Evasion for Laborers and Drivers), initiating a long-term research roadmap that will facilitate design choices for work zone safety technology. The SHIELD platform will provide realistic yet safe learning environments in which data on future workers' evasive behavior in various struck-by-hazard scenarios can be measured in order to inform the human-technology safety partnership. The VR training modules resulting from this project will improve the workers' mental model of the wearable device capabilities and overall situational awareness, thereby enabling workers and organizations to formulate new safety strategies afforded by the newly augmented physical capabilities. The scientific insights on learning and adaptation across a diverse range of workers will help make the technology designs more inclusive and effective and ensure equitable workforce diversification. The eventual aim is to make the SHIELD Platform scalable and transferable to several other work contexts with struck-by hazards, either by vehicles (e.g., fire respondents, towing, waste removal, roadside assistance, and law enforcement) or by falling or flying objects (e.g., mining, general construction, oil, and gas).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With a convergent focus on the innovative opportunities that future technologies hold to significantly enhance and bolster the safety of American workers—particularly those laboring in the often hazardous environments of roadside construction sites (e.g., often at the risk on incoming vehicles colliding with them)—the dedicated and multidisciplinary team embarked upon a comprehensive investigation. The primary objectives of this initiative were threefold:

First, the team aimed to develop a virtual reality (VR) testbed designed specifically for conducting experiments that are based on reconstructed work zones situated within virtual environments. This endeavor allows for the simulator to be used in any form of feasibility experiments, such as predicting the impact of different notification technologies or other safety mechanisms to ensure worker safety (e.g., it allows, for example, to measure a worker’s reaction time to a safety event, such as incoming car—all of it simulated safely in virtual reality, without the need for complex and extremely costly physical experiments). To achieve this, we implemented an initial simulator using Unity3D and a VR tracking apparatus that enables future researchers to create and simulate an incoming car collision scenario within a worker zone located at the side of the road. This tool, therefore, provides a safe and controlled environment in which different potential solutions can be thoroughly tested and evaluated to enhance worker safety in real-world situations.

Second, the project team explored the initial design of an innovative wearable device. This device delivers targeted haptic stimulation to its wearers (e.g., roadside workers, thereby alerting them to critical and potentially life-threatening conditions, such as the approach of incoming vehicles. This device and future devices designed using our insights might improve the situational awareness of workers, effectively reducing the risks associated with their exposure to traffic and enhancing overall safety.

Third, the team engaged in a rigorous quantification of various models concerning roadside worker safety, which included a analysis of risk factors that contribute to accidents, understanding promising new smart technologies designed to improve safety protocols and practices for these workers. The insights gained from this analysis serve as a foundation for future developments in worker safety technology.

Beyond the tangible artifacts produced as a result of this multifaceted project—such as the advanced VR simulator and its associated physical setup, which has now been successfully installed in two separate laboratories for ongoing experimental research, as well as the innovative design of a new safety device—the project also fostered a rich exchange of knowledge between the fields of computer science and civil engineering. We expect that this interdisciplinary collaboration will foster novel solutions aimed at enhancing the safety of workers in roadside environments.

Furthermore, the project resulted in the generation of several scholarly publications, the creation of valuable artifacts, and the training of students across various academic levels, including undergraduates, PhD candidates, and postdoctoral researchers. Notably, one of our undergraduate students, who played a vital role in the programming of the VR simulator, was honored with the prestigious Computing Research Association (CRA) Undergraduate Honorable Mention Award, recognizing their exceptional contributions to this project and highlighting the impact of their work within the broader context of computing research.

In conclusion, this innovative project not only lays the groundwork for new developments in smart technologies aimed at improving worker safety but we believe the scientific insights will contribute to more research in safety. The artifacts produced, including the VR simulator specifically designed for roadside safety worker scenarios, serve as instrumental tools for future research and development, ultimately contributing to a safer working environment for individuals engaged in roadside construction and related activities.
